title: Women World Cup final tickets nearly 20 times cheaper than men , say fans in Australia
body_text:
England football fans in Australia who have bagged seats for the historic Women’s World Cup final this weekend say tickets were so cheap it was “bordering on ridiculous” in comparison to prices fans pay for men’s football.
Emily Taylor, 45, from Cheshire, bought pre-sale tickets to every game nearly a year ago, when the highest priced category one tickets were between £50 to £60 for the final match.
“It’s incredibly affordable,” Ms Taylor told i. “I’m amazed more people didn’t jump on this in October when they were released.”
By comparison, tickets for the men’s World Cup final in Qatar were priced between £156 to £1,223, according to football news website Goal.
“Compared to the men’s, it’s incredibly cheap, almost bordering on ridiculous,” Ms Taylor said of the ticket prices for this Sunday’s match between England and Spain.
“I think it’s been undersold, it could’ve been double the price for the final and I would’ve happily paid it.”
With a day to go before the final, England and Spain fans have been anxiously refreshing the Fifa website for a chance to watch the match at Stadium Australia in Sydney.
Toby Holloway, 32, who relocated to Sydney from Kingston Upon Thames, said he managed to get tickets on Thursday – for A$40 (£20).
“The cost of the ticket to me is insane,” he told i.
“The whole discussion about there not being enough money in women’s sport, but then I’m paying $40 for a ticket through Fifa less than three days before the final, it’s absurd.
“I was probably willing to pay $200 or $300, which would be about how much you’d pay for a men’s [World Cup] ticket.
While Fifa officials said the tournament sold more than 1.5 million tickets in just six days last month, beating the previous record of around 1.35 million in 2015, sales in New Zealand – which jointly hosted the 2023 tournament with Australia – were so slow that sponsor Xero gave away 20,000 for free in July.
Ms Taylor, who has been in Australia since mid July to watch the tournament with her wife, Mel, said it was a “slow burn” at the beginning, with only a handful of people watching matches at bars.
Since then, momentum has been building and there are now about 100 England fans packing into some pubs to watch the World Cup.
“It’s everywhere you turn, every billboard in Sydney has a women’s footballer on it and buildings with massive photos of our star players on it,” she said.
“When we started in Brisbane there was probably 20 or 30 of us, now there is over 100 of us at the pub.”
Australians are also getting involved too, Ms Taylor said, despite losing to England in the semi-final on Wednesday.
“There hasn’t been any nastiness, you can walk around in your shirt and you get Australians say ‘good luck to ya’,” she added.
While some Australians have come to say they will be supporting Spain this Sunday, Mr Holloway said it was to be expected.
“The rivalry between England and Australia is fierce, it always has been, especially after the Ashes,” he said.
As Britons in Australia, Mr Holloway and Ms Taylor are excited to be part of history.
“I think England has a really good chance,” Mr Holloway said. “I know a lot of people are really jealous that I’m going.”
Ms Taylor added: “We’ve had an epic four weeks. I couldn’t be prouder to be a tiny part of this massive, positive experience.”
Jake Fewell, 23, a chartered accountant from Essex on a six-month secondment in Sydney, told i he is looking forward to the “once in a lifetime” opportunity to see England play in a World Cup final, after he secured a batch of tickets at $80 (£45) each for himself and his colleagues.
He and his workmates decided to try to get tickets after watching the semi-final in the fan park at the Allianz Arena. When they saw a new batch was being released on Thursday, they “jumped at the chance and managed to get 14, the exact number we needed for us and the other Brits on secondment in our office”.
He has been following the Lionesses since the Euros final last year, when England won 2-1 against Germany, and has says “Australia has been a great host country that has really promoted the women’s game”.
“Every Aussie and Pom – as the locals call us – I know has been gripped with World Cup fever,” he added. “There’s been a great atmosphere in Sydney throughout the whole tournament. It’s such a multicultural city and this tournament has been a great thing in common for so many people.”
Mr Fewell added that he is “excited but nervous” for the final match on Sunday, but asked for his prediction on the final score, said: “Got to be 3-0 to England, bring it home!”
The Aussie rooting for England
Isabella Matti, a 19-year-old student from Sydney, has been trying to get tickets for the final, after being “absolutely wowed” by the tournament so far, and said she will be “rooting for England to win”.
“I’ve been trying to message people through Twitter and Facebook but it’s just absolutely full of people attempting to scam others for money,” she told i. “So I’ve also been persistently refreshing the official Fifa ticketing site and hoping for the best.
“A lot of people I’ve spoken to have had the same dilemma. This tournament has definitely introduced a whole new cohort of fans into not only football, but women’s football.
“I feel like this has caused a lot of people to scramble for tickets last minute, as they’ve unexpectedly fallen in love with watching the games.”
Ms Matti said she was “lucky enough to attend the semi-final”, which she called a “fantastic game”, adding that she had “never heard a crowd roar as loud as when Sam Kerr scored that absolute banger” for Australia.
As a Chelsea supporter, she has been following women’s football at club level, and thinks it is “extraordinary” how the women’s game has “progressed into what it’s become today”.
“I love watching many members of the squad individually: Alessia Russo, Ella Toone, Lauren James, Jess Carter… It’s such a nostalgic and sentimental feeling, one that I particularly remember when I was younger and watched men’s football.”
She said that “being a woman and watching other young women become so successful in an area that was previously dominated by men is just really beautiful to witness”.
“I also think it’s important to remember that female footballers aren’t looking to be compared to men, rather, they are simply playing the game they grew up loving and enjoying,” she added.
Ms Matti said she is “buzzing” for the final, as “it’s such an incredible achievement for both teams”.
“There is so much talent in amongst both squads and I genuinely don’t know how the game will end.
“England did beat Spain during the European Championships last year, and they played some beautiful football against Australia too.
“My heart says England will win and Russo will be on the score sheet. Then again though, Spain have Putellas and Bonmatí in their team, arguably some of the best players in the world.
“However, I’m predicting a 2-1 win for England.”
Erin Bailey, 23, who has just finished university, decided while watching the semi-final to travel from her home in Palmerston, New Zealand, to Sydney on Saturday to see the final.
She told i that she “sat on the Fifa resale site for about two hours refreshing the page, and finally, when I was about to give up, one came up for NZ$120 (around £56)”. She is also paying NZ$918 (£460) for her flights, and will be flying back on Monday.
Ms Bailey said the Lionesses “have such a good bond” and she has been following them since the 2015 Women’s World Cup. “Seeing them play at that tournament made me fall in love with the style of play they used.”
She said it is “the biggest football match I have ever been to, so it’s going to be an absolutely insane experience.
“I can’t wait to watch two world-class teams put on such a great game, and to see the best players in the world.
“I think England will win but I believe it will go to penalties.”
